docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate overwhelmingly approved a bipartisan bill to provide prescription drug coverage under Medicare this week while a partisan Republican bill barely squeaked through the House by a one-vote margin. That sets the stage for a bitter struggle in a conference committee where one can only hope that the bipartisan spirit prevails. Both bills couple a drug benefit under Medicare with a ''reform'' that seeks to inject more private-sector competition into the entire Medicare program. The bills have been sharply condemned by conservatives who complain that they do too little to encourage private plans and by liberals who find the drug coverage skimpy. Even so, it makes sense to move forward with the best parts of each bill after years of stalemate on the issue.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional leaders rejoiced today over passing legislation to help the elderly buy prescription drugs, but they said they would need weeks, and perhaps months, to work out differences between the versions approved by the Senate and the House early this morning. The task of achieving a compromise was complicated by an extremely close vote in the House, where conservatives said they feared that Medicare costs might explode with the addition of new drug benefits.

headline.main: House and Senate Face Big Job To Settle Medicare Differences

docs.lead_paragraph: Linda Chopra and Linda Sperry, a lesbian couple from Cleveland, were planning to come to Toronto for a librarians' convention anyway. But when they read the news that Canada was now recognizing same-sex marriage, they decided to fill their trip with a whole lot more than the latest tips about reference books. They came to the Toronto city hall this week, where the rainbow gay flag now flies on the roof to celebrate Pride Week and the new social revolution going on inside, and filled out a marriage license application, which still has blanks for bridegroom and bride.

headline.main: A Few Gay Americans Tie the Knot in Canada

And it was Republicans, led by President Bush, who pushed it through.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States economy grew more slowly than previously thought in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said today. There were signs, though, of potential improvement in the job market. The gross domestic product increased at a 1.4 percent annual rate in the quarter. That was less than the 1.9 percent pace estimated a month ago and matched the lethargic pace in the final quarter of 2002.

docs.lead_paragraph: After a severe test of President Bush's influence on Capitol Hill, the Senate and the House today approved the biggest expansion of Medicare since its creation nearly four decades ago, passing legislation to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly and give private health plans a much larger role in the program. The House vote was 216 to 215 in a dramatic roll-call that lasted more than 40 minutes, with the ''nays'' outnumbering the ''yeas,'' until several Republicans switched their votes. Conservative Republicans joined most House Democrats in voting against the bill in a setback for the Republican leadership and for President Bush, who had lobbied intensely for the measure for months. The vote came around 2:30 a.m., shortly after the Senate cleared its version of the bill by an overwhelmingly bipartisan vote of 76 to 21.

headline.main: House and Senate Pass Measures For Broad Overhaul of Medicare

docs.lead_paragraph: Fire marshals will no longer investigate most car fires. There will be 3,500 fewer police officers compared to three years ago. Inmates on Rikers Island will not get intensive drug counseling. And most city libraries are now open five days, instead of six. It is hardly the kind of thank you that New Yorkers might expect after being asked to pay higher income, sales and property taxes in the fiscal year that starts Tuesday. But despite those cuts, New York City government will offer an array of services that is still more generous than it was early in Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's tenure, when New York faced its last major fiscal crunch. And the cuts agreed to this week by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council are just a pittance compared to the wholesale reduction of basic government operations that occurred during the mid-1970's fiscal crisis.

headline.main: FEARS ASIDE, CITY AVOIDS STEEP CUTS

docs.abstract: Budget cuts agreed to by Mayor Michael R Bloomberg and New York City Council are pittance compared to wholesale reduction of basic government operations that occurred during mid-1970's fiscal crisis; despite Bloomberg's dire warnings earlier this year, most New Yorkers will find it hard to discern any difference in services they are accustomed to receiving from their local government; city's $44 billion budget will return city to service levels common before Mayor Rudolph Giuliani went on second-term spending spree, expanding city programs with surpluses fueled by Wall St; new budget means city-taxpayer-financed spending will have increased 2.7 percent in first fiscal year of Bloomberg's tenure and 4.9 percent in his second year; most pressing question in minds of professional budget watchers is whether Bloomberg and City Council cut enough, given extra burden imposed on city residents through higher taxes and fees; chart (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it planned to pay $622 million to settle an investigation into sales practices for liquids needed to feed the seriously ill. The company said in a statement that it would take a charge of 34 cents a share in the second quarter to cover a settlement of a ''previously disclosed civil and criminal investigation'' of its Ross Products division. Abbott earned $592.3 million, or 38 cents a share, in the second quarter of last year.

headline.main: Abbott to Pay $622 Million To End Inquiry Into Marketing

docs.lead_paragraph: HCA Inc., the hospital chain, will pay $631 million to resolve health care fraud allegations, the Justice Department said yesterday. HCA, based in Nashville, announced the settlement in December, though it still required approval from Justice Department officials in Washington. The agreement resolves allegations that the company filed false Medicare reports and paid doctors kickbacks to refer patients to company hospitals. HCA, formerly known as Columbia/HCA Healthcare, pleaded guilty to 14 criminal counts in December 2000 and later reached a separate settlement with Medicare. The company said yesterday it took an aftertax charge of $468 million in its fourth quarter, which ended in December.
